prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Rumbling Bumble-thumbaloo
’Twas brundledawn, and skritchy lanes
Did blibble by the tempestitous gloam,
All murmerfused the concrètes-manes
Where strangers rummage home.
“Beware the echobrumble, lad!
The scrappletsnap, the call-cast creep!
Beware the brassy thunder-glad
And shun the whirloweep!”
He took his plunkish voice in hand,
Long time the smog-ghost sought—
So rested he by the gruff-voicéd stand,
And brimbled well a thought.
And as in gravel-gnarled thought he bray’d
The echobrumble, eyes of moan
Came bargust-blabbing through the shade,
And quobble-wobbling alone!
One two! One two! And through and through
The tunnel-bones did burrish-sing;
He left a note—a warplink yow—
And came thrumbumble-ring.
“Hast spooked the thaumathroat?” said he.
“Come to my hearth, my beamish throat!
O frabbulant day! Hollo-ray! How free!”
He chortled in his coat.
’Twas brundledawn, and skritchy lanes
Did blibble by the tempestitous gloam,
All murmerfused the concrètes-manes
Where strangers rummage home.
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "The Rumbling Bumble-thumbaloo" present before first stanza, non-empty and separate.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 8 stanzas total; 7 stanzas are quatrains (4 lines each), 1 stanza line count uncertain due to line breaks but overall consistent with 4 lines; meets ≥70% quatrain and stanza count ≈3–8.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Lines generally alternate longer and shorter lines in most stanzas with ~2+ content-word syllables difference (e.g. “’Twas brundledawn, and skritchy lanes” longer, next line shorter). Pattern holds in ≥60% stanzas.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Most stanzas (≥60%) appear to have rhymes in lines 2 and 4, allowing slant rhyme (“gloam” / “home”, “creep” / “whirloweep”); rhyme pattern AABB avoided as rhymes do not strongly dominate first pair lines; mostly ABAB or ABCB like forms.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes the first stanza with ≥2 repeated content words/phrases: “’Twas brundledawn”, “skritchy lanes”, “Did blibble”, “tempestitous gloam” repeated exactly; clear ring composition.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition stanza present: Second stanza begins “Beware the echobrumble, lad!” clearly an admonition or warning to protagonist.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Third stanza shows preparation: protagonist “took his plunkish voice in hand,” “long time the smog-ghost sought,” “rested… and brimbled well a thought” - indicates planning/prep before encounter.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Fourth stanza depicts encounter: “And as in gravel-gnarled thought he bray’d / The echobrumble… came bargust-blabbing… alone!” - clear meeting with creature/adversary.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Fifth stanza depicts decisive action: “One two! One two! … tunnel-bones did burrish-sing; / He left a note—a warplink yow— / And came thrumbumble-ring.” Presence of action that resolves tension, though abstract, parallels the ‘snicker-snack’ killing action.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Sixth stanza shows celebration/return: “Hast spooked the thaumathroat?” “Come to my hearth, my beamish throat!” “O frabbulant day! Hollo-ray!” and chortling in coat all indicate joyful return and jubilation.</C10_think>
<C11_think>At least 8 distinct coinages present: brundledawn, skritchy, blibble, tempestitous, murmerfused, concrètes-manes, echobrumble, scrappletsnap, call-cast, brassy thunder-glad, whirloweep, plunkish, smog-ghost, gruff-voicéd, brimbled, gravel-gnarled, bargust-blabbing, quobble-wobbling, burrish-sing, warplink, thrumbumble, thaumathroat, frabbulant, hollo-ray. Well above 8 distinct invented words.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one evident coinage, scattered coinages appear in all 8 stanzas.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Named creature “echobrumble” is central; protagonist warned about it, encounters it, acts against it; thus non-canonical named creature central to action.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia present: “scrappletsnap,” “brassy thunder-glad” (some sound-based), “burrish-sing,” “warplink yow,” “thrumbumble-ring” - multiple sound-effect coinages, arguably ≥2 onomatopoeic bursts.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance clear in multiple stanzas, e.g. “brundledawn, and skritchy lanes,” “bargust-blabbing,” “brimbled well a thought,” “rumbling Bumble-thumbaloo,” “scrappletsnap,” “call-cast creep” - several stanzas with deliberate alliteration and consonance.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Tone is playful, whimsical, somewhat mythic/fantastical with invented compound words and surreal coinages echoing Jabberwocky style.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No lines exactly match canonical poem lines; wording fully original or transformed with new coinages.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens used: “’Twas” only (common poetic contraction), “And,” “He,” “One, two!” internally parallel to original but not repeated verbatim phrases; other canonical token usages appear low. Probably ≤8 distinct canonical tokens, favoring coinages.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable counts roughly track Jabberwocky pattern: longer lines ~8–9 syllables, shorter lines ~5–7 syllables in majority of stanzas (~5 of 7 have suitable meter). Meets ≥60% threshold.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhymes (2,4) vary across stanzas: “gloam/home,” “creep/whirloweep,” “sought/thought,” “flame/alone,” “burrish-sing/thrumbumble-ring,” “throat/coat,” “gloam/home” repeated only in ring; few repeated end words, no overdominant rhyme ending beyond the ring echo.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No single content word reused excessively outside ring echo, e.g. “echobrumble,” “brundledawn,” “skritchy,” all distinct; usage is spread and not dominated by any one word (well under 5 uses or 8% content word frequency).</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages show large diversity with at least 10+ distinct roots and no single coined suffix dominates >50%; e.g. “-ing,” “-ed,” “-y,” “-aloo,” “-led,” “-cast,” “-snap,” “-sing,” “-ring,” no dominant pattern.</C22_think>

prompt: Compose a poem on morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Fogwock’s Dawning

’Twas brilly in the mornlight, and the slithy mist
Did wyrm and wobble through the groves of sleep;
All mimsy were the dewdrops, kissed
By vapours that the hedgerows keep.

“Beware the Fogwock, wanderer!
The breath that blinds, the hush that hums!
Beware the shroudrat, murmurer,
And shun the dimdrum doldrums!”

He took his vorpal lantern bright,
He sought the snicker-snack of dawn;
Through whiffled paths of pearly white
He quested where the shadows yawned.

And as in muffled thought he stood,
The Fogwock, with its vapoury eyes,
Came swirling through the ashen wood,
And burbled vapours to the skies!

One, two! One, two! The lamplight cleaves!
The beam went snicker-snack!
He left it blinded in the leaves,
And went a-wandering back.

“And hast thou slain the Fogwock, lad?
Come beamish to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas brilly in the mornlight, and the slithy mist
Did wyrm and wobble through the groves of sleep;
All mimsy were the dewdrops, kissed
By vapours that the hedgerows keep.
label: high
judge_raw:

<C4_think>In ≥60% stanzas, lines 2 and 4 rhyme, e.g. "hums"/"doldrums" and "sleep"/"keep". Slant rhyme present and no AABB dominance detected.</C4_think>
<C5_think>The final stanza closely echoes the first with ≥2 repeated content words/phrases ("brilly", "mornlight", "slithy mist", "mimsy", "dewdrops") forming a clear ring composition.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition present with direct warning: “Beware the Fogwock, wanderer!” and further admonitions of “shroudrat” and “dimdrum doldrums.”</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation visible: protagonist “took his vorpal lantern bright” and “He sought the snicker-snack of dawn,” showing armament and resolve before encounter.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Clear encounter occurs: "The Fogwock, with its vapoury eyes, / Came swirling through the ashen wood," indicating confrontation.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive action present: “One, two! One, two! The lamplight cleaves! / The beam went snicker-snack! / He left it blinded in the leaves,” resolving the conflict clearly.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration stanza present: “And hast thou slain the Fogwock, lad? / Come beamish to my arms...” with jubilant tone and callooh callay.</C10_think>

<C21_think>No single content word is overused beyond reasonable bounds; no problematic lexical repetition.</C21_think>

prompt: Create a poem about déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Slipping-Back of Borrance Street

’Twas trigalume and the slipstrings slid  
Through yesternooks where memories hid;  
Each footfall faltered on snorpatch stone—  
I’d walked here once in twilight’s moan,  
For through the chinkèd air arose  
A hush that knew me, cap to nose.

Beware the Déjà Vogga, child!  
It reedy grins with clocks gone wild;  
Its lampleyes glitter twice preset,  
Replay whatever you scarce have met.  
He took his Nimblerod in grip,  
And—flibberance! —let reenact slip.

Then sauntering past, by clockface pale,  
The Stiltplop came, a clk-clk-clk tale;  
Its shadow scurried half-ahead,  
Already planted where I tread.  
One footfall forward—one footfall back—  
The sidewalk bowed upon its track.

It stampish-struck at trysts postponed,  
It butterclashed the ever-gowned;  
It flashed me flashcards of a dream  
I swear I’d fed the sewer-stream.  
But past the fog-lamped, stuttered gleam  
I hugged my Nimblerod and screamed.

O frabjous loop! Calloo, callay!  
I sliced the rerun clean away;  
Yet from the sliced-off chrono-rind  
The echo-smell sneaked back, behind.  
And every step I brew anew  
Still twitters, “Tick—was this not you?”

So trigalume and slipstrings slide;  
Still yesternooks in whispers bide;  
Still Borrance Street re-spiels its play  
With phantom prints for yesterday.  
Come twilight moan or pocket sun—  
The Vogga grins: The film’s not done.
label: medium
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "The Slipping-Back of Borrance Street" present preceding first stanza, non-empty and separate from stanza text.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 6 stanzas; stanza line counts: 6 lines, 6 lines, 6 lines, 6 lines, 6 lines, 6 lines; no quatrains. Less than 70% quatrains and stanza count outside 3–8 quatrains range. So no quatrain shape.</C2_think>
<C3_think>No quatrains, cannot assess alternating longer/shorter lines in quatrain pattern. Lines mostly similar in length with no clear long/short alternation; criterion not met.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme scheme present but more complex stanza forms with 6 lines; some rhymes occur (e.g., hid/slid; child/wild; pale/tale), but (2,4) rhymes specifically not consistent or dominant; AABB patterns not observed but (2,4) rhyme is not reliably present across stanzas.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Last stanza echoes opening stanza tone and some words about "yesternooks", "twilight moan", "still" repeated concepts but no exact repeated content words or clear refrain phrase repeated from first stanza; partial thematic echo but no ≥2 repeated content words/phrases.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition stanza is present: second stanza includes "Beware the Déjà Vogga, child!" and warning phrases; full admonition fitting requirement.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Protagonist prepares before encounter: takes "Nimblerod in grip", "hugged my Nimblerod and screamed" indicating a tool held and preparation/resolution present.</C7_think>
<C8_think>There is a clear encounter/confrontation: "Then sauntering past, by clockface pale, The Stiltplop came, a clk-clk-clk tale"; the named entity "Stiltplop" presents obstacle and interaction described.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive action: "I sliced the rerun clean away" is decisive, cutting through looping déjà vu; suggests resolution to central tension.</C9_think>
<C10_think>No clear depiction of return/homecoming or celebration; last stanza is reflective rather than triumphant, no jubilant acknowledgement found.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Coinages: trigalume, slipstrings, yesternooks, snorpatch, chinkèd, Déjà Vogga, lampleyes, Nimblerod, flibberance, reenact slip, Stiltplop, clk-clk-clk, stampish-struck, butterclashed, fog-lamped, chrono-rind, echo-smell, brew anew, phantom prints; more than 8 distinct coinages present.</C11_think>

<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance clearly in multiple stanzas: e.g., "slipstrings slid", "memories hid", "flash me flashcards", "stuttered gleam", "butterclashed", "chrono-rind". More than 2 stanzas show notable alliteration/consonance.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Tone is whimsical and mythic, with playful neologisms and a mysterious motif akin to a mythic riddle, rather than a flat or prosaic style.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No lines are exact matches to canonical poem lines; all wording is original.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens are very few or none; mainly new coined words with references only to "Beware", "O frabjous", and maybe "Calloo, Callay" phrase; canonical tokens count ≤8.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable pattern less tight than Jabberwocky’s alternating ~8 and ~6 syllables; lines vary in syllable length and stanza lines are 6 not 4 lines; no clear consistent ballad meter pattern.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme endings reasonably varied across stanzas; no repeated end word more than twice; rhyme pattern complex and varied; rhyme variety criterion met.</C20_think>

prompt: Write a poem about desire path in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
THE WISH-WORN WAND’ROADS

’Twas twisky in the semesterlune,  
As skimbled scholars left the gate—  
All puckish were the shortcuttsuune,  
And the squirmfelt paths sedate.  

Beware the Desyrwyrm, my tread!  
That bends the blade, that leaps the lawn!  
Beware the Temptaslip, and shun  
The thorneye Timebegone!  

He took his pedalped feet in hand:  
Long time the asphalthope he sought—  
So traded tarmac’s measured bland  
For cowslip-printed thought.  

And, as in kurfling mood he stepped,  
The Desyrwyrm, eye of flame,  
O’er scliffish clods and dribbled slopes,  
Skritt-scratched a narrow name.  

One,选择! 选择! 选择! And through and through  
His soleprints pressed the greeny seam;  
The grass lay flat, the daisies bent—  
It almost smelt of dream.  

“And hast thou slain the Sidewalk King?  
Come to my arms, my beardless swain!  
O freckled day! O freelanced way!”  
He chorled in his brain.  

’Twas twisky in the semesterlune,  
As skimbled scholars mocked the course—  
But still a thread-weak track festooned  
The quad with booted force.
label: high
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title present as a separate non-empty line before first stanza: "THE WISH-WORN WAND’ROADS" -> yes</C1_think>
<C2_think>Stanzas = 7 total; stanza line counts are all quatrains (4 lines); 7 stanzas within 3-8 range and 100% are quatrains -> yes</C2_think>

<C4_think>(2,4) rhyme mostly present, e.g. gate/sedate, lawn/shun, sought/bland, flame/name, seam/dream, swain/way, course/force. No AABB dominance, mostly ABCB rhyme scheme. >60% stanzas have (2,4) rhyme with some slant rhymes -> yes</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes the first with repeated themes/words: ‘’Twas twisky in the semesterlune,’ echoes first stanza; “scholars” repeated; use of a "thread-weak track" and "booted force" echoes the opening’s "skimbled scholars" and "shortcuttsuune." At least 2 content words repeated or refrained -> yes</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition present in stanza 2: “Beware the Desyrwyrm, my tread! ... Beware the Temptaslip, and shun...” all cautionary -> yes</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation armament before encounter in stanza 3: "He took his pedalped feet in hand; Long time the asphalthope he sought— So traded tarmac’s measured bland For cowslip-printed thought." This shows deliberate preparation/resolution -> yes</C7_think>
<C8_think>Clear encounter in stanza 4: "And, as in kurfling mood he stepped, The Desyrwyrm, eye of flame, O’er scliffish clods and dribbled slopes, Skritt-scratched a narrow name." The Desyrwyrm appears and meets the protagonist -> yes</C8_think>

<C11_think>Invented coinages counted: twisky, semesterlune, skimbled, shortcuttsuune, squirmfelt, Desyrwyrm, Temptaslip, Timebegone, pedalped, asphalthope, kurfling, scliffish, dribbled (arguable), skritt-scratched, thread-weak, booted force (compound?); well over 8 distinct invented coined words beyond canonical -> yes</C11_think>

At least two stanzas with strong alliteration/consonance beyond incidental repetition -> yes</C15_think>
<C16_think>Tone whimsical/mythic: The poem’s tone is somewhat playful, imaginative, with invented words and mythic-like quest imagery -> yes</C16_think>

prompt: Compose a poem on conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Flibberflop Convenery

’Twas Q-four-score across the froth,
   Where memoscope threads do burble,
Did gurgle-grin the spindled clot
   In swarthy tele-swurlburble.
From chart to chart the gauzeflap fling
   The quimbler-phones went tootering;
A sabulous jargon-harm they bring
   Through quiverline ogre-circlings.

“Beware the Projectionbeam, my son,
   The blur that hives, the glass that slips!
Beware the flickering glazing-stun,
   And shun the fruitless Bullet-Quips!”
He decked his face in visi-mask,
   With laser-stylus poised to task;
Sought crystal cube of slidy-flask—
   Then pranced to causeure of the past.

By glypheny screen, mid flickering glord,
   The whiteboard klickrake snickered,
A roiling mist of scrambled word
   Around his bent shoulders bickered.
One, two! One, two! Through saline gloam,
   The laser stylus spun and shome!
He zapped the lurking Framin’thrume—
   That fatal automatic slome!

“Has thou, my boy, the Framin’thrume slain?
   Come hug me, bulbous ventricle!
O zerkical day! Exultate main!”
   He clangeth within his frenticle.
’Twas Q-four-score across the froth,
   Where memoscope threads do burble—
He baked the plots, he crunched them both,
   In biscuit-slick certification-burble.
label: high
